newsitem.title: USA: Fundamentals drive up U.S. foreign crude prices.
newsitem.headline: Fundamentals drive up U.S. foreign crude prices.

text.p: Fundamentals were seen driving up foreign crude prices in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday, keeping most buyers on the sidelines, traders said.

"Domestic grades are getting expensive, the North Sea is tight....things seem to have bottomed out for the time being," said one crude seller. "The market looks pretty constructive for the next couple of weeks."
The supply-demand balance was tightening for both ends of the crude spectrum, traders said.
The tight North Sea market and a narrow spread between West Texas Intermediate/Cushing and Brent were boosting regional and domestic sweet grades.
The August WTI/Brent spread was around $1.25-30 a barrel on Tuesday afternoon.

Meanwhile, sour grades were moving up in response to the delay in the resumption of Iraqi crude exports under the U.N. oil-for-food deal. Iraqi Kirkuk and Basrah grades were not expected to re-enter the market until late July or early August at the earliest.

From the North Sea, a Norwegian company was showing Brent for around 20-25 cents a barrel under WTI for first-half August delivery. The same seller was also offering Oseberg at around the same price for end-July arrival.
West African availabilities were more plentiful. A U.S. company was close to selling 450,000 barrels of Nigerian Qua Iboe for $1.93 a barrel over Dated Brent for first-half August delivery.
A U.S. company was still looking for a home for 950,000 barrels of Qua Iboe for end-July, asking the cif equivalent of around 40 cents a barrel over Dated Brent fob.
A trading house was showing Forcados for August 10-20 at Dated Brent plus $1.75 a barrel, a price buyers deemed very aggressive.
A European company was also heard offering a waterborne cargo of Odudu, although this could not be immediately confirmed.
In Latin America, a top Argentine producer was showing one million barrels of Canadon Seco crude for loading in the second half of August.
Elsewhere in the Southern Cone, Chile and Uruguay were seeking to buy around one million barrels of crude apiece for August delivery in separate crude tenders, traders said.
Chile's state oil company Empresa Nacional del Petroleo (ENAP) was seeking to buy 960,000 barrels of crude oil for August 14-18 delivery.
Bids will be received and the tender awarded on Wednesday.
Uruguay's state oil refiner ANCAP was seeking to buy one million barrels of crude for August 18-28 delivery.
The Uruguayan tender will be awarded late on July 3.
Among regional sour crudes, Ecuadoran Oriente was on offer at $3.05-10 a barrel under WTI for August, while the Venezuelans were heard asking a discount "tighter than $3.00" for Mesa-30.
